Award.AwardTitle: EAPS: Determining the Niche Dimensions Associated with Invasion and Speciation of Meghimatium (Pulmonata: Philomycidae) In Japan

POR.DRECONTENT:
I performed two studies about the ecology of Japanese philomycid slugs: 1) a project to understand if Meghimatium bilineatum, a possible introduced species to Japan, has the ecological and physical characteristics of an invasive species and 2) a comparison of the ecology of Japanese philomycid species. I hypothesized that 1) M. bilineatum is found more often in human-disturbed habitat than M. fruhstorferi, a known native species. I also hypothesized that 2) the Japanese species of Meghimatium are ecologically distinct. I surveyed slugs in natural and disturbed habitats across much of Japan (Honshu and Okinawa) in order to capture the range of environmental conditions occupied by each species (Fig. 1) and to determine which habitat characteristics and food preferences distinguish species. The GIS program DIVA was used to match GPS coordinates of slugs to existing maps of habitat characteristics (land cover type, human density, altitude, precipitation, temperature, seasonality). 

As expected of a probable “weedy” invasive species, 1) M. bilineatum is smaller than M. fruhstorferi, and found in locations with much higher human populations. Habitat type use is distinct, with 84% of M. bilineatum occupying cultivated or urbanized land while 62% of M. fruhstorferi were found in intact forests. However, M. bilineatum feeds primarily on algae covering tree and rock surfaces rather than crop plants, suggesting that it would not be an agricultural pest. I selected four groups of observed slugs (M. bilineatum, M. fruhstorferi, and Okinawan Meghimatium species with “striped” and “plain” forms) to compare ecologically. 2) M. bilineatum and M. fruhstorferi are ecologically distinct. M. fruhstorferi occupies higher elevations and cooler habitats with more precipitation. M. fruhstorferi shares few habitat types with and occupies cooler and higher sites than Okinawan Meghimatium. Although partly geographically separated, the two Okinawan Meghimatium species forms (striped and plain) are very similar in size and ecological habits. This accords with existing genetic data that show them to be the same species but different than M. fruhstorferi.

Dr. Rei Ueshima, of the University of Tokyo, Bunkyo campus, was my advisor for this project. He studies the systematics (species relationships) of landsnails and slugs and their phylogeography (relationships of individuals and species across space), and so he was able to advise me on the localities, anatomy, and known relationships of philomycid slugs. Dr. Ueshima provided me with training in DNA extraction and slug dissection. He and his graduate students introduced me to specimens of many of the landsnail species that they study, and I assisted them with some landsnail collections on Okinawa. 

This study provides an overview of philomycid habitat requirements and an update to their ranges, both of which have been poorly known. My observations on the ecology and behavior of M. bilineatum help to confirm its likely non-native species status, although no evidence was found that it is pest of cultivated plants. The dataset produced will be incorporated with information on North American and Asian philomycid slugs for additional studies.
